node.text:
Breaks feel so good.... AND I am back and inspired and happy to "see" you! 

Recently we held a challenge all about knowing kids and simultaneously learning yourself: thinking differently about behavior. Investigating. Pausing. Responding. 

A prime time for this…. Enter bedtime. 

Bedtime can be a time for warm bath, cozy books, togetherness...

and it can look like the opposite: kids running in circles sans diapers, us worn out adults, the sillies and a side of yelling to ignite some guilt for later.

I am inviting you to a **Live popup video talk** TOMORROW: Tuesday at 2:30pm EST in my NEW Facebook group. 

We will continue this trailblazing path of thinking differently about "coregulation" and what is needed in the moment to ease the tough situations, understand behavior and make the meaningful ones even better. 

Share your bedtime and behavior questions here in comments and I'll incorporate a handful of them in tomorrow's conversation! 

You will be let into the Facebook group a few minutes before we start. 

See you in 24 hours 😴

node.text:
Excited to gift you all this conversation on conscious interaction and @nekole.amber sharing powerful bits of her parenting experience and how breaking patterns of “do more” has been liberating to both her emotional regulation and relationship with kids.

She tells us what she does for a “conscious conversation” after messing up, and the power of kids seeing their adults in full humanity, mistakes emotions and all. 

Full video linked in stories. 

Have you experienced similar mindset shifts, and how so?

node.text:
Both big and small transitions and change can be "threatening" to our nervous systems, especially for kids wired to be fully in the moment to nurture their development - and resistance can often result 

In this video I share an interactional "way" toward the connection that carries all through it.

Unintentionally, this became a way to boost connection, laughter and help everyone's "adapt and adjust" brains kick in - plus connect to our playfulness and authentic spirit at the core.

In the video I speak to one example - getting out the door - and would love to hear how you will use this in other situations!

It may seem as if it “takes time” yet it builds cooperation versus that time spent in coercion that feels good to... *nobody.*

node.text:
A child is screaming, whining, crying. Let’s talk two options👇

One: use our adult power, strength, and big-ness to fear kids out of whatever they're doing, or

Two: choose relational "coregulation" (despite how small or trivial you feel the problem may be), be present, curious, set compassionate limits, and cultivate their ability to move through discomfort and tough stuff on their own down the road.

The (many) problems with option one: while it stops the behavior, it doesn't allow the neurological emotional cycle to complete, it eats away at relationship and diminishes the child’s sense of self.

Kids don't learn to feel, accept, and release emotion - they learn to numb it, avoid it, shut it down, or fixate on it. In the later years this may mean overdrinking, overdoing, or chronic mental health challenges. Anyone relate...??

Option two allows them to figure out how to feel human emotion and manage resulting behaviors. They learn that emotions are safe, part of life, and they have the ability to observe it, feel it, and find healthy ways to cope..most of the time.

1. Observe: who needs to be regulated first, them... or us??
2. Validate + Normalize 
3. Problem Solve

Watch this IGTV for a breakdown.  Register for the Meltdown Method course via link in profile if you want to continue on...Three days left to get a spot or until spots fill.

Here it is. 

The little moments become the big ones when it comes to guiding kids through tough stuff.  It may seem they’re upset about the popsicle when it’s actually deeply rooted grief or frustration about loss of routine or seeing friends or feeling the weight of the world. 

Have you noticed shifts since choosing Coregulation?

node.text:
Try this for kids arguing. Fighting. Physicality causing everyone a visceral jerk reaction. 😬

Many (most?!) of us adults are still working to figure out needs and wants and get clarity. How great if we have a way to help kids get there sooner?? Yet lots can get in the way when it activates our own old unresolved “stuff” or we don’t have foundational needs met in the moment.

See the NEED for yourself - then see the need beneath the behavior for both kids.

This sneak peek of the Bonus Module dives into this common challenge that can really shake the day to day.

If you’re wanting more - the meltdowns course is enrolling now linked in profile. It gives you opportunity to talk real time examples for these situations that can be really nuanced AND help them get through conflict in safe enough ways versus feel the need to constantly jump in to the rescue.

node.text:
What happens when a child has a meltdown, you get down at their level and they escalate further? 😡😳

When our great compassionate words and curiosity and all of the conscious supportive things are met with “stop it!!” Or “ I hate you!!” ? 😐

We will never be perfect at attuning to others, knowing what they need and 30% “helpful attunement” is a very “enough” human goal.

Yet what to do when it seems over time that something isn’t working? How to know if we are on track or need to adapt?

In this video I talk through three things to help.

While this behavior *can* let us know we need to try a different approach, or check our own emotions and energy in the moment, it absolutely doesn’t always mean we are doing something “wrong.”

After watching: here are some questions for you to think about to “measure” our effectiveness. 

✨How connected do you feel along the way: Is it “you against me” or “this is tough and we are in it together”? 

✨Are they getting to connected tears of sadness or spiraling in control and upset?

I planned some time today to answer questions and comments you have- comment below with thoughts!

node.title: When these great strategies don’t “work”! What does this mean?

node.text:
Our bodies constantly take in information about the environment, reading subtle cues and perceiving either safety or threat.

The more we cultivate connection, ease, and safety, the more a child's nervous system can organize, adapt, and engage in daily life versus get stuck in a reactive, disorganized, dysregulated state.

Through Coregulation we literally enable the development of higher brain states.

Yet what might this look like in real life??

In this IGTV video I share 3 ways to coregulate:

1. Body Position

2. Pace

3. Tone

The neat part is - these tips just happen to regulate our own nervous systems, too.

Watch the video as I talk through simple, interactive ways to work this into a challenging part of the day many of you shared - the morning routine - and let me know your thoughts, questions, if implementing some of these has shifted your life.

node.text:
Because our responses, the experiences they carry, and their body connection and security become the tools they'll internalize and pull from again and again -- through the free and easy times 🥳and the ones that rock their worlds.🥺

Here are four big things I think about off the bat when it comes to cultivating emotional regulation and resilience for life. This “list” is not exhaustive - what do you want to know more about? What did I miss? What questions do you have? Comment below and I'll be answering throughout the day.

node.title: Boosting Emotional Regulation through Daily Life

node.text:
Our society tends to be a monster that promotes relying on external feedback or on our "facade" - looks, houses, cars, achievements, how things look on the outside - in an attempt to feel okay.

This week, we've been talking about different ways we can break away from this through daily actions.

In this IGTV I'm sharing one of my favorite ways to relate - Witnessing.

Sometimes, we all need a cheerleader and praise is by NO MEANS a "bad" thing. Yet talking with clients lately, it's fascinating how some of our most well intended praises can work against our values and goals in relating to others.

Maybe it's simply about witnessing the human experience in front of us, and sharing ours with them. Connecting through the tough moments, connecting through the celebratory ones, being PRESENT for one another versus focusing on just the right thing to say or ramping up the guilt when things don't feel aligned.

If this resonates: Check out the video for examples of what exactly to say and help kids to move THROUGH a totally healthy human emotional cycle versus getting stuck in unhelpful patterns for the long haul - plus why starting by witnessing YOURSELF may be the most important work of all.

Here's to a generation of humans that maintain that inner sense of worth and embodied esteem we're all born with, basking gracefully into the enoughness.

node.text:
@thrivinglittles So often being over our “sensory threshold” can show up in seemingly unrelated ways.

We feel overstimulated and suddenly have difficulty regulating our body temperature.🤯

We get irritated at all of the multi tasking and suddenly we need everything to be quiet.🤫

Similarly - we never really know the root of kids’ behaviors.

👖Sometimes it’s that they had a rough night of sleep or that kid said something mean at school and suddenly they’re irritated by their jeans tag.

🍲Others they are putting all of their resources into sitting still at school and when they get home there aren’t any leftover to work through the unexpected dinner item.

🥺Others they may dislike something simply because they want us to witness them in their pain or “feel badness” and emotionally release in some way. 

Whatever it is- try these steps to guide.

As always, if this type of interaction shifts just a little bit we can make things significantly easier on kids.✨

Where do you struggle with this?

node.title: 4 STEPS to Guide Kids through Discomfort ⬆️

node.text:
Eye contact is a sign of regulation👀

Kids are learning what works for them. 

Our sensory systems constantly adjust and work together. When we boost resources in one area, we open more for another.

Maybe eye contact is a bit visually overstimulating, so they adjust and adapt and listen closely while moving around, shifting gaze. 

Maybe they don’t feel totally emotionally comfortable with this person yet, therefore avert gaze to reduce their sensory demands and engage. 

Whatever the reason - when we let it be and engage in other ways, we allow space for them to adjust from the inside out.

More in stories

You're being sensitive" thrivinglittles'.

node.text:
One of the most common coping methods in the book when we feel uncomfortable:

make it about someone else. 

Some of our most primitive, reactive ways of dealing with our own dysregulation are to blame, shame, defend, hop on the high horse that feels so pseudo-good for a short time. 🐎

Only the high horse comes with big sacrifice - relationship, connection, the self-regulation that makes life rich and meaningful and allows us to be truly present versus swept up in the monkey mind. 

When we haven't learned to regulate our own nervous system, we often detach from it all together and miss the cues, sensations there - we attempt to "regulate" by controlling, blaming, criticizing others or kids.

If only they were different, I would be okay.

When we become aware of our own discomfort and dysregulation, these start to shift. 

We rewrite and focus on the kid, hopping beyond the self-absorption of centering. 

We notice the *reaction*, then choose how to *respond.*

1️⃣Whew, I'm taking this personally right now and I know it isn't about me.
2️⃣Is there anything valuable or true in this criticism? How can I be present to hear it."
3️⃣Ouch, it's clear that I impacted this child in what I did/said. Let's pause for a minute and allow them time to express"
4️⃣This kid is hitting/having a really hard time and they need me to coregulate. 
5️⃣Looks like I have open wounds to deal with regarding their mother/father. This child's emotional experience is their own.

This doesn’t speak to abuse or indicate that people aren’t ever at fault - it’s that the majority of the time, our inner world is where the shift happens. ✨

What would you add?

node.text:
1️⃣Acknowledge the EMOTION, then the BEHAVIOR. 

2️⃣NARRATE to help them UNDERSTAND from the inside out. 

3️⃣Give space for them to FEEL. 

4️⃣Don’t *actually* expect them to care or have perspective taking in the moment. The key is understanding right now, not empathy just yet. 

Empathy is a felt experience, not something we can tell them to “do.”

Struggling with moving from “this kids driving me crazy” to empathy? It isn’t too late to join me in LIVE conversations in our trailblazing program THRIVE - all about embodying, connecting with the wounds within, showing up through tough situations and owning this empathy from the inside out. Two ways to join us in profile

How does this land for you?

#pediatricoccupationaltherapy #respectfulparenting #consicousparenting #siblingsbelike #connectionovererfection

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Katie Crosby | OT on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We can't "teach" kids empathy. Empathy is learned through interaction through caregivers showing empathy toward them. @thrivinglittles'.

node.text:
Empathy and compassion are felt experiences, sensations in the nervous system that say “I don’t know exactly what you’re feeling, but I know pain, and I’m willing to be with you in yours.”

It isn’t about words. It’s about cultivating presence for someone else in their messiest, least “acceptable” moments.

This cannot be taught.

Only experienced, learned through hundreds of interactions of others holding positive regard for kids in their messy moments.

We hold unconditional positive regard for kids' behavior. 

This does NOT mean condoning behavior that harms or letting them hit or throw things around because they're angry. 

It means you are the strong wise adult that notices, yep, this child is having a hard time. No matter their intelligence or age or what I know they can do outside this moment, in this moment - they need some coregulation, even as simple as space held to block the hitting, to remove the objects being thrown, to letting the emotion beneath the behavior BE. 

From this being and acceptance and trust that adults are on their side, they're able to be on the side of fellow humans in need.

They're able to say, hey: we may disagree and the way you're expressing yourself isn't perfect, and I know I'm human and imperfect and have these same core emotions too. 

Through that, compassion grows.

They learn that other humans' emotions and perspectives are entirely their one, and we can get curious about that. 

When did you experience empathy as a child?

node.text:
CENTERING:
When kids say something or do something “I don’t like you” or hit and adults say 

“That makes me sad”
Or blame the child’s character “you’re being too sensitive”

It is typically rooted in ADULTS feeling  uncomfortable, struggling to regulate and self soothe, + taking this typical kid behavior personally as a result and/or fear they won’t have empathy down the road. 

It is rooted in not having that discomfort coregulated as a child, therefore not being able to identify what is coming up and why and take ownership.

The truth is: *we cannot be empathetic unless we are regulated.* regulation is core to all.

How to avoid this now?
Set limits around behavior or words to build safety and security for us as the adult 

AND remember kids *need* adults present through these tough moments to hold space and coregulate in order to develop their own tools to manage from the inside out -

No matter how regulated they seem, if they’re showing these behaviors it’s a sign they’re in their primitive brain state- fight flight freeze - and their impulse control and language centers are offline.

Accepting and validating THEIR discomfort is the way to boost their capacity to activate their impulse control, to access language - while also regulating our own discomfort right alongside them.

node.text:
When we can *Slow the Moment* enough to RESPOND versus REACT - 

After getting in the way and blocking any true physical harm - 

We lead with the body, we trust nonverbal communication, clear our energy -

and allow everyone opportunity to move from the primitive brain state (fight flight freeze) to one where everyone can access those higher level tools that go out the window beforehand.

From this sense of security, their *own* internal capacities to shift their behavior grow.

Sometimes your own resources may not be there to slow yet this practice boosts the brain and emotional regulation for life. Worth it? You decide… one interaction at time.

#consciouscaregiving #pediatricoccupationaltherapy #nervoussystemregulation #emotionalregulation #emotionalintelligence #respectfulparenting #intentionalparenting #consciousparenting

node.text:
Our best attempts to share boundaries and limits in the moment of big emotion will go in one ear and out the other.

When kids are in fight flight mode our best bet is to help their nervous system restore feeling SAFE.

It isn’t the time to teach or direct or punish.

These things are so well intended yet just aren’t effective for building the brain for emotional regulation in the short or long term.

From this SAFETY their brains can adapt, their impulse control can click back online, their brain literally rewires to RESPOND instead of REACT (read: hit 🥊)

And we heal, as adults, right alongside them.

Tomorrow we kick off a trailblazing five weeks walking through these scenarios real time in my newest program. It is rooted in experiences and stories and how I shifted one interaction at a time and have witnessed many families do the same. If this calls to you - join us to T H R I V E in profile. 

Part 2 will share what I do next

#sensoryprocessing #meltdown #tantrum #overstimulated #parentinghack

node.text:
Physical grounding = emotional grounding 

The best kind of sensory bin: the earth. The ground. Unrestricted movement to roam. 

Our connection to our body and surroundings and earth sets foundation for our emotional regulation, consciousness, self esteem to name a few.

…and this doesn’t stop at infancy or childhood.

Yesterday I shared a FREE mini masterclass on stepping into power. Grounding energy in ways that impact all involved. 

Link is in profile to enter our brand new Thriving Beings Facebook group and watch the Live playback to center in on the capacities within you.

How do you get grounded?

node.text:
Do you agree?

Those scenarios that continue to repeat, the times we feel most “stuck” can often be traced way back in some way - no matter what we call them.

When it comes to navigating kid behavior - wild bedtimes, hitting, kicking, biting, big feelings - this can be a key to unlock the potential of the relationship and guide.

Today I’m holding an entirely free LIVE mini-masterclass on the Energy of Limit Setting: the energy we unknowingly bring to relationships with kids and others in our lives. Join our new Facebook group in profile and the conversation will be available to you indefinitely if you can’t make it live!

You’ll learn that often the views we hold tell us significant things about the weight we carry, the heavy energy that comes up in tough behavioral moments.

Look forward to your thoughts.

node.text:
Breaks feel so good.... AND I am back and inspired and happy to "see" you! 

Recently we held a challenge all about knowing kids and simultaneously learning yourself: thinking differently about behavior. Investigating. Pausing. Responding. 

A prime time for this…. Enter bedtime. 

Bedtime can be a time for warm bath, cozy books, togetherness...

and it can look like the opposite: kids running in circles sans diapers, us worn out adults, the sillies and a side of yelling to ignite some guilt for later.

I am inviting you to a **Live popup video talk** TOMORROW: Tuesday at 2:30pm EST in my NEW Facebook group. 

We will continue this trailblazing path of thinking differently about "coregulation" and what is needed in the moment to ease the tough situations, understand behavior and make the meaningful ones even better. 

Share your bedtime and behavior questions here in comments and I'll incorporate a handful of them in tomorrow's conversation! 

You will be let into the Facebook group a few minutes before we start. 

See you in 24 hours 😴

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Katie Crosby | OT in Petoskey, Michigan. May be an image of 1 person and brick wall.

node.text:
It feels much of my life to this point has been an inhale - doing, shifting, changing, creating, learning. 

Finding my passion. Moving through the pain and joy that inspired it. Learning, organizing, planning, hustling to be able to live it.

Seeing the problems in how we as a society view kids and emotions and digging away to find the deepest root of it all - those parts that bring healing from the ground up: Interaction. Connection. Belonging. 

The parts we live daily in relationships with kids, others, ourselves. 

I am taking time this month to be with all that has happened and shifted externally, but most profoundly - internally.

To integrate. To take space from social media however feels aligned. 

It feels like the beginning of a long, slow exhale.

Exciting things to come around here. 

Thankful for you all, and sending care whether you’re in an inhale or exhale of your life.

node.text:
Excited to gift you all this conversation on conscious interaction and @nekole.amber sharing powerful bits of her parenting experience and how breaking patterns of “do more” has been liberating to both her emotional regulation and relationship with kids.

She tells us what she does for a “conscious conversation” after messing up, and the power of kids seeing their adults in full humanity, mistakes emotions and all. 

Full video linked in stories. 

Have you experienced similar mindset shifts, and how so?
